history.content: Yep, no techs that are contributing to your degree can be P/NP, but you're all good on that.

children.subject:
An email titled "College of Engineering Policy and Procedure Update for Fall 2016" was recently sent out. Relevant portion:
New Policy Regarding Grading Option for Non-Degree Technical Courses Beginning Fall 2016, if you are taking a technical course that cannot be used to fulfill any requirement for your major, you may elect to take the course on a pass/no pass (P/NP) basis if you choose the P/NP option by the end of the fifth week of classes. Keep in mind that many COE majors include a minimum number of technical elective units or engineering units, so if the course you are taking can count toward those unit requirements, you must take it for a letter grade. Please check with your adviser if you are unsure if the course can count toward your major requirements. This policy is effective Fall 2016. There will be no retroactive changes to grading option for courses completed prior to Fall 2016.
Do you have a reference to something that shows that?

history.content: this is correct, please see below quoted email

I've heard that in my last semester, if I have fulfilled all my technical requirements I can take technical courses as P/NP. I have been searching for official documents that state this, but I haven't been able to find any. I am in EECS and have fulfilled all requirements to graduate except my final upper division humanities course. I want to take two technical courses this semester as P/NP, along with my last humanities class. Will I be able to do that?
history.subject: Taking Technical Course as P/NP
